item.title: Auditor cronyism, festival sex crimes, Öresund ID checks, Almedalen "nationalism"
item.description:
Revelations of corruption at National Audit Office, dozens of sex offenses reported at Swedish festivals, commuters still face grueling journey from Denmark to Sweden, and the take away from Almedalen

One of Sweden's three auditor generals steps down after revelations of corruption at the National Audit Office. Swedish summer festivals have been getting a lot of attention, but for troubling reasons: the number of sex crimes reported. We talk to the organizer of one festival that's been in the headlines, and we hear from the National Council of Crime Prevention.How do you cure a headache that's held on for half a year? Commuters in southern Sweden would love to know. Hear from Francois, whose daily trip home from work has become a grueling journey, ever since the Swedish government instituted double ID checks for folks travelling over the Öresund bridge.And after the big political week of Almedalen wrapped up, Dagens Nyheter's political commentator, Ewa Stenberg, who covered her first Almedalen in 1993, points out that many of the party leaders' speeches involved a new element this year: nationalism.Producer / presenter: Brett Ascarelli

item.title: Almedalen Week, a license to work and female sailors
item.description:
Sweden's annual political gathering Almedalen is underway but is attending it worth the cost? And could a driver's license help integrate immigrants into the Swedish workplace?

Also, the Central Bank keeps the nation's key interest rate unchanged at its current historically low level. And, Radio Sweden climbs aboard with a skipper who wants more to encourage more women to take part in the sport of sailing.Producer: Frank Radosevich.

item.title: Brits becoming Swedes, Brexit and business, Bergman on Fårö
item.description:
Brits apply for citizenship in record numbers. Experts tell us how a Brexit vote may affect Swedish politics and economy. And Bergman Week kicks off on Fårö.

The Migration Agency told us that the average waiting time for Britons who want to apply for Swedish citizenship was over a year. But one of our followers says he became a Swede in just a few days.And we hear from two British nationals who live in Sweden about their takes on the referendum (just before the England-Iceland match at a pub in central Stockholm). Political science researcher Nicholas Aylott explains how the Brexit vote might affect Swedish politics going forward. And economist Anna Brehmen explains how the Swedish economy stands to be affected.An author working on a book about Ingmar Bergman says even if you don't like his films you might be impressed by his ability to direct and manage several romantic affairs simulatneously. And Aleksander Gabelic, president of the UN Association of Sweden, speculates on what direction Sweden might take on recognizing Western Sahara now that it's won the election for a UN Security Council seat.Producer: Vincent Cavalier

item.title: Brexit vote, Zlatan steps down and how to celebrate Midsummer
item.description:
Will Britain stay or go? As the country votes to decide its future with the EU, we find out what a Brexit could mean for Sweden.

And despite heavy criticism Swedish lawmakers this week approved legislation that clamps down the nation's asylum rules. Plus, Swedish football star Zlatan Ibrahimovic steps down from the national team and Midsummer celebrations ramp up before the weekend. Producer: Frank Radosevich.

item.title: Pilot strike, remembering Gothenburg's riots, a summer singalong
item.description:
A SAS pilot strike is over but who's to blame? Maybe it's you. children, some as young as nine, were placed in isolation at state-run homes. And Sanna Neilsen is ready to sing this summer.

Producer: Frank Radosevich.

item.title: Scandals, miracles and a long awaited Gothenburg concert
item.description:
Lavish spending in the Swedish Church. Trade union hoping for a fresh start. Hate speech sites and mainstream media. Sweden's second saint. Plus: why people have been queuing all week in Gothenburg.

How the Swedish Church was found to use millions of parish money for leisure trips abroad, with premier league football, sightseeing and alcohol.Members of Sweden's biggest trade union take stock of the effects of the scandal in their organisation.They call themselves "alternative media", others call them "hate speech sites" for their inflammatory anti-immigration standpoint. Now a new study for the Institute for Media divides them into three groups. There're the ones who preach to the already converted, and confirm their world view. There're the ones that want to influence mainstream media, which they feel do not tell the whole truth. And then a third group, who see it more as a business opportunity.At the Vatican on Sunday, Sweden's second saint, Elisabeth Hesselblad, will be canonised. We find out how the Catholic Church goes about actually prioving that someone is behind a miracle.And then we find out what all the buzz is about in Gothenburg this weekend, where people have been queuing all week to try to get space close to the stage in Ullevi Stadion.Producer/presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.title: Cabinet reshuffle, Austrian elections, Astrid Lindgren award, no tobacco?
item.description:
Analysis of PM Löfven's cabinet reshuffle, lessons Sweden may learn from the Austrian presidential elections, meet novelist Meg Rosoff, and smokers sound off on the idea to widen the smoking ban.

Should the Prime Minister have shaken things up more when he announced how he would reshuffle his cabinet on Wednesday? Hear why political scientist Marja Lemne, researcher at Stockholm University, believes so.In Sweden, some see it as a warning signal that a far-right candidate in Austria almost won the race to become head of state there. For example, the former foreign minister, Carl Bildt, tweeted that there were lessons to be learned. We talk to Niklas Ekdal, a Swedish journalist who used to serve as political editor of the newspaper Dagens Nyheter, about what these lessons might be.With World No Tobacco Day coming up on May 31st, smokers get a little fired up, especially about the idea to widen the ban on smoking to include outdoor cafes.And meet author Meg Rosoff, who's written several young adult novels, including one about a pregnant teenager who gave birth to a baby moose. Rosoff won this year's Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award for children's literature, which she will receive at a ceremony at the Stockholm Concert Hall on May 30th.Producer / presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: Genocide trial, the new Greens, women in robotics
item.description:
A Stockholm court convicts a man for participating in the Rwandan Genocide. The Greens declare a "new start." And an international robot conference visits the capital.

In this week's edition of Radio Sweden Weekly a Swedish prosecutor speaks about a first-of-its-kind trial decision against a naturalized citizen who is accused of leading and participating in massacres during 1994. And Radio Sweden's reporter visited Karlstad for the Green Party's national conference. She discusses the mood of the party as it declared a "new start" and formally elected a new party co-leader.And as an international robotics conference visits Stockholm, we hear from one organizer about why there are so few women in the field.And our reporter shares what it was like to sit amidst Russian and Ukrainian journalists at the Eurovision Song Contest finale held in Stockholm last Saturday.

item.title: Radio Sweden Weekly: Eurovision comes to town and the Greens choose new leaders
item.description:
Sweden's Environment Minister Åsa Romson stepped down, as Isabella Lövin was nominated as new co-leader of the Green Party. We bring you the inside story, plus a historical look at Eurovision.

We also discuss what the Green Party crisis means for the environment, with the editor of influential green blog Supermiljöbloggen, Beatrice Rindevall. And consider what role Eurovision has played in Sweden's history, and its international relations, with historian David Lindén.Producer: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: Eurovision and Swedish music exports
item.description:
The attraction of Swedish songwriters. The strength of Swedish music exports. The possible origin of the Swedish music "phenomenon".

The Eurovision Song Contest this year is a very Swedish affair. Not just because it will be held in Stockholm, as a result of last year's win, but also because a quarter of the songs - eleven out of 42 - have been fully,or partly written by Swedes. In today's programme we meet Sara Biglert and Christian Schneider, who have written this year's Czech entry, and learn a thing or two about how to pen a song for Eurovision.We also visit a music school for kids - Popskolan in Åkersberga - an example of the publicly funded institution that the world-famous Max Martin once hailed as the secret behind Sweden's music success. The head of the lobby organisation Swedish Music Exports, Jesper Thorsson tells us why he thinks Swedish artists and songwriters are doing so well abroad.With 18-year-old Isa on her way to stardom, her manager and dad Mattias Tengblad shares his thoughts on what the Swedish selection for Eurovision can mean for a young artist. And Swedish Radio's powerful music editor Karin Gunnarsson explains the relation between Eurovision and the rest of the Swedish music scene.Presenter and producer: Ulla Engberg

item.title: Greens' drama, vague terror threats, King's 70th, how to enjoy taxes
item.description:
Who will the Green Party choose to lead it out of crisis? How do terror-threat warnings affect the psyche? How many will celebrate the King's birthday? And why one American loves paying Swedish taxes.

In this episode of Radio Sweden Weekly, we continue following the drama of the Green Party after spokespersons Åsa Romson and Gustav Fridolin announced they are willing to step aside, depending on what's decided at the Greens' upcoming congress.This week, media reported that the Swedish security service Säpo had received information about a possible terrorist attack. Säpo said they'd gotten information that they couldn't dismiss, but wouldn't go into any details. We take a look at the psychological effect that reading vague information about possible terrorist threats can have.We also host a debate between a republican and a royalist, as the Swedish King Carl XVI Gustaf celebrates his 70th birthday. And, with the last day to declare taxes in Sweden coming up on May 2nd, we find out why one American is so excited about the Swedish way of filing.Guests: Henrik Torehammar, Filip Arnberg, Magnus Simonsson, Sara Skyttedal, Thomas Heberlein. Producer / presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: Radio Sweden Weekly: A bad week for the Greens
item.description:
A rocky time for the newest party in government, the Greens, as a minister resigns. Radio Sweden's reporters discuss what this crisis means.

Presenter Loukas Christodoulou is joined in the studio by reporters Frank Radosevich and Brett Ascarelli, who have also been looking at Swedish reactions to the US presidential race.And the actions of the state-owned power company Vattenfall are putting more pressure on the weak red-green government, as its coal burning is heating up the climate. Swedish Radio science reporter Ulrika Björkstén explains what's happening.Plus Radio Sweden Arabic reporter Samar Hadrous discusses her work investigating jihadism in Sweden, as a suspect from Malmö is held in Belgium over alleged links to Paris and Brussels attacks.

item.title: Radicalization in Sweden, the economic sap of ID checks
item.description:
What's Malmö doing to fight radicalism? Economic costs for ID checks, Police on extra money in spring budget: not enough, Sweden's UN Security Council campaign, British citizens in Sweden on Brexit

In this edition of Radio Sweden, we speak with terrorism expert Magnus Ranstorp about Rosengård, the home-town neighborhood of the 23-year-old Swede arrested in connection with the attacks in Brussels.And we speak with Per Tryding, from the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Southern Sweden, about the economic costs of ID checks to the Malmö-Copenhagen region.We hear from a police officer about the challenges that police face in Sweden's northern parts when they have to perform deportations.Reporter Ulla Engberg gives us an overview of the latest in Sweden's campaign for a seat on the UN Security Council.And we hear some of Loukas Christodoulou's interviews with British citizens who live in Sweden but who are thinking about the official start of the EU referendum campaign.Producer / presenter: Vincent Cavalier.

item.title: Outrage over Panama Papers, EU-Turkey migrant deal
item.description:
Aftermath of Mossack Fonseca leak, human rights and the EU deal with Turkey on migrants and refugees, why collective bargaining is different this year, and the Swedish Scholastic Aptitude Test.

In this edition of Radio Sweden, we look at a few of the top stories in Sweden this week. We talk to Sharon Rider, a philosophy professor at Uppsala University, about why people are so outraged by the Panama Papers, even though it's still unclear whether laws have actually been broken. We also ask the UNHCR whether it's realistic for the Swedish government to hope that human rights will be respected as migrants and refugees are deported to Turkey due to a new EU deal. Reporter Loukas Christodoulou explains why this year's round of collective bargaining negotations, which set terms for pay and working conditions, is so unusual. And we look ahead to a big event this weekend, one involving thousands of pencils and multiple choice questions. The Swedish Scholastic Aptitude Test (Högskoleprovet) takes place Saturday, and we talk to one of the nearly 88,000 people who have registered, Sam Faraji Bidi, about his hopes that it will help him get into college. Producer / presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: 'Here Dances Mr. Cucumber': Lennart Hellsing's legacy
item.description: He wrote some of Swedish children's favorite rhymes - full of word play, fantasy, and literary nonsense. Writer and translator Lennart Hellsing recently died at the age of 96.

item.title: Sweden's reaction to Brussels attacks and its fight against terrorism
item.description: After bombs hit Brussels, Sweden's prime minister expressed shock and sadness and says we must defend our "open society". We discuss in depth what this means. Presenter: Loukas Christodoulou

item.title: The personal ID number - and why every Swede has one
item.description:
Personal ID numbers: why have Swedes got them, what are they used for, and what is it like to live here without one?

A ten digit personal ID number is how Swedes identify themselves in their contacts with the authorities. But also when they go to the bank, sign up for the gym or the phone company. Should we be worried about how they are used? And what's it like to live in Sweden if you haven't got one? In today's programme we'll take a closer look at the personal ID number and its role in the Swedish society. Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.title: Boulevard to climate change: The fuss over a roads report
item.description:
Sweden wants to be best in the West on climate. So should the country still plan for more vehicles?

Producer: Vincent Cavalier

item.title: Refugees still welcome? Sweden's asylum shift
item.description:
After welcoming some 163,000 refugees last year, Sweden is now trying to push through legislation that would make seeking asylum here much more difficult.

But has the country gone from publicly declaring "refugees welcome" to an about-face on its asylum policy?In this episode of Radio Sweden Weekly, we look at the nation's evolving refugee policy, how it's changed and what it means for asylum seekers and activists alike. Producer: Frank Radosevich

item.title: Domicile dash - scrambling for housing in Sweden
item.description:
The housing shortage: a glimpse of the demand, a look at the profits to be made, and why more isn't being built.

In this episode of Radio Sweden, we take the temperature of the housing market, and at an apartment viewing in central Stockholm, it proves to be very hot. Then, we hear the story of what it's like to buy a rental contract on the black market, and finally, we hear about the housing shortage from a builder's perspective.Producer: Brett Ascarelli.

Then, we hear the story of what it's like to buy a rental contract on the black market, and finally, we hear about the housing shortage from a builder's perspective.Producer: Brett Ascarelli.

item.itunes:subtitle: The housing shortage: a glimpse of the demand, a look at the profits to be made, and why more isn't being built.

item.title: Are Swedish universities going downhill?
item.description:
A debate over the state and future of academia is raging in Sweden after one professor complained that higher education is in shambles.

The university is no longer a place for enlightenment. Students have too much power and politicians and administrators favour quantity over quality.Thats one side of an argument that's been raging in Swedish academia and beyond for some days now. It all started with an opinion piece that opened the floodgates, with academics, students and politicians weighing in.So, are universities going downhill? Radio Sweden puts the question to student union reps, a professor and a group of exchange students to find out what those inside the ivory tower are thinking.Producer: Nathalie Rothschild

item.title: Reproductive rights and the future of men
item.description:
As single women get the right to access fertility treatment in Sweden, what does it mean for the future of families - and of men?

Being single is no longer an obstacle to forming a family. Starting April, single Swedish women will be able to access state-funded fertility treatments on the same terms as heterosexual and same-sex couples. That's thanks to a legal amendment that was passed by parliament earlier this month. So women can now become single mothers with a little help from the public-health system.But there's already a shortage in sperm, with too few men stepping forward to meet the demands of couples who need help getting pregnant. With at least 2,000 singles expected to seek fertility treatment in the next year, clinics are trying to recruit new donors. Radio Sweden has visited one of those clinics, run by associate professor Kjell Wånggren.But what are the incentives to donating sperm anyway? And if women no longer need partners to get pregnant, does that mean men are obsolete? Historian Lars Trägårdh puts the whole issue of single parenthood in perspective - and considers what it might mean for men in the future.We also speak to members of two of the organisations that have been at the forefront of the fight to extend fertility treatments to singles: the Swedish Association for Sexuality Education (RFSU) and Femmis, a network for single-mums-by-choice. They describe the move as "a victory for single women" and as an important signal that society is beginning to accept all kinds of families.Not everyone agrees, though. We hear a dissenting view, from Emma Henriksson, deputy leader of the Christian Democrat Party, which opposed the new law, arguing it goes against the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.Producer: Nathalie Rothschild

item.title: Free speech, Nordic Noir and the children’s book boom
item.description:
As Sweden marks the 250th of the Freedom of Print Act, we take a look at the state of free speech and publishing in Sweden.

The 1766 Freedom of Print Act was a landmark for the expansion of free speech in Sweden, but Radio Swedens (unscientific) survey suggests that few Swedes know about this ground-breaking document. We also delve into the vaults at the National Library in Stockholm where the original pamphlet is kept, and we explore what threats still exist to freedom of expression today. The freedom of print has also taken on a whole new meaning in recent years as just about anyone can write a book and self-publish it online these days. That's part of the explanation behind the recent boom in children's literature. We find out just what is meant my norm-critical childrens literature and we meet a Eurovision star turned childrens book author. And of course, Nordic Noir is still going strong. It seems like new crime novels are published every week in Sweden. But is crime the only genre that works abroad or can Swedish authors who write other kinds of books make it internationally, too? We speak to publishers and authors with different takes on the matter. Produced by Nathalie Rothschild.

item.title: Radio Sweden's News Review of the Year
item.description:
Radio Sweden looks back at the stories that hit the headlines in the past year, including the migrant crisis, the terrorism threat and a school attack which shocked the nation.

Dave Russell looks back on a dark and heavy year for news in Sweden with the help of opinion writers, Hanne Kjöller from Dagens Nyheter and  freelancer Per Wirtén.

item.title: Sweden's north: from myth to reality
item.description:
The myths of Christmas are tied to the north of Sweden in many people's imaginations. But what is the reality of living there for the indigenous Sámi people who have been there for centuries?

The idea of the north is essential to understanding how Swedes picture their country and themselves. And the idea of the north is also crucial to understanding how the whole world sees Sweden. But Sweden is a long country, stretching northwards towards the North Pole, and the vast majority of Swedes live in its bottom third. Many have never even visited the northern half.How can we separate the myths of the north from the reality? Radio Sweden's Ryan Tebo takes a journey ascending into the darkness of the northern Swedish winter, exploring the myths and realities surrounding Christmas and the north.First stop: Santaworld in Mora to interview Santa and explore how the myths of Christmas are connected to Sweden and the north.Last stop: Kiruna, where Ryan visits the Nutti Sámi Siida, which is a living living of Sámi culture and history. There he meets reindeer up close and interviews Káren-Ann Hurri about being Sámi and living in the north. Afterwards, Ryan meets with Sámi leader and activist Matti Berg at his Icelandic horse and ecotourism farm, Ofelas.Program produced and presented by Ryan Tebo.

item.title: Hallandsåsen - A look back through the tunnel that kept running into trouble
item.description:
It took 23 years to build and killed hundreds of cows and fish in the process. This week we look back at one of the most scandal-plagued projects in Swedish history, the tunnel through Hallandsåsen.

The tunnel finally opened for regular traffic on December 13, 16 years behind schedule. The project suffered a number of setbacks since it was started in the 1990's, the worst of which in 1997 when a chemical sealant leaked out into the ground water and poisoned livestock in the area.In this episode of Radio Sweden weekly, we visit some of the towns surrounding the Hallandsås ridge and ask people living north and south of the tunnel how the infamous construction project has affected them and what they think about the project today.

item.title: It's year 2100. Are there crocodiles in Sweden?
item.description:
Travel into the future with Radio Sweden to find out how the country could change as the global temperature rises.

As world leaders meet in Paris to find a way to keep climate change under control, we wind the clock forward...To help us imagine how the area around Stockholm City Hall - and beyond, might look 85 years from now, we take a stroll with Dr. Henrik Carlsen, a senior research fellow at Stockholm Environment Institute. Then you'll hear from the leaders of tomorrow, as Francesca and Autumn, two kids in town for a climate conference of their own, who talk about what action they believe is key to keeping the planet in good shape.Visit a lab aiming to produce next-generation fuel with the help of bacteria, and find out what the head of the research group, Dr. Paul Hudson's, thinks of when he sees the color green. And finally, meteorologist Martin Hedberg gives the weather forecast for December 10th, ... 2100.Music credit: 808 and Moog Out (Podington Bear) / CC BY-NC 3.0Program produced and presented by Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: Twenty years after Dayton: Stories of war, justice and politics
item.description:
The stories of three Swedes whose lives were, in different ways, deeply affected by the war in Bosnia.

The conflict in Bosnia was by far the bloodiest of the Yugoslav wars. Around half of the country's population fled their homes and thousands settled here in Sweden. Radio Sweden brings you the stories of three Swedes whose lives were deeply affected by the war, which officially ended 20 years ago with the signing of the Dayton Accords, a US-brokered peace deal. On December 14th 1995, the leaders of Bosnia, Croatia, and Serbia signed the General Framework Agreement for Peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina - or the Dayton Accords. They signed it in a Parisian palace, surrounded by European heads of state, world leaders and international organisation chiefs. But for many of those who had lived through the war, it was too little, too late. Produced by Nathalie Rothschild.

item.title: The fires hitting refugee centers
item.description:
A look at a spate of fires that have hit refugee centers to find why they're happening, who's behind them and what people are doing to stop them.

This year, there have been more than 20 fire-related incidents at asylum accommodations in Sweden - from Boden, just below the arctic circle, to Arlöv, just across the sea from Denmark. Thirteen alone took place last month in October.In many of the cases, police suspect the flames were started deliberately. So far no one's been arrested. But ever since the arson attacks picked up pace in mid-October, security has been a top concern for the authorities. After a fire in Danderyd and another arson attack at a planned refugee center in southern Sweden, the Swedish Migration Agency decided that it was no longer safe to have a public list of addresses of its planned and established refugee housing. The agency is also placing stricter rules on visits to places where asylum seekers are living. It's hard to say for sure if the measures are working but the string of suspicious fires tapered off at the end of October.

item.title: Safety and politics after Trollhättan school murders
item.description:
It's been a week since a young man stabbed two people to death at a school in western Sweden. The attack has raised questions about security in schools and the political atmosphere in this country.

It's Thursday - a week ago to the day since the slayings at Kronan school in the segregated neighborhood of Kronogården in Trollhättan, near Gothenburg. Police have determined that racist motives were behind the actions of 21-year-old Anton Lundin Pettersson, when he walked into the school wearing a mask and carrying a sword. Pettersson went on a rampage, stabbing people. He killed a student and an assistant teacher, and later died after the police shot him.In the aftermath of the stabbings, which some people never predicted would happen in this country, Radio Sweden looks at whether there should be more security at schools here in Sweden, how people are coping with the emotional impact that the attack left in its wake, and whether the political atmosphere in Sweden could be creating room for violent hatred to latch onto.Presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: How to win a Nobel Prize...
item.description:
Winning a Nobel can change your life - and make it harder to travel. Is there a formula for winning? And we speak to one critic, who tells how he won £400 betting on the Literature Prize.

It's Nobel Prize season in Stockholm, and in this second-ever episode of Radio Sweden's weekly podcast, find out tips for winning a Nobel Prize, from the author of Write Like a Nobel Laureate, Kristian Fredén, and from the curator of the Nobel Museum, Gustav Kjällstrand. Hear from Professor Brian Schmidt (Nobel laureate in Physics, 2011) how winning a Nobel can change your life - and make it harder to travel. And critic and editor Christian Lorentzen, who hasn't won a Nobel himself, tells how he won £400 betting on the Literature Prize. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli with Gaby Katz.Thanks to Nobel Media and Nobelprize.org for permission to use interviews with some of the laureates in this podcast. The full interviews can be found at www.nobelprize.org.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-09-30 kl. 15.00
item.description: As almost a quarter of a million cars are to be recalled in Sweden, we look for some insight into what kind of atmosphere might have contributed to the Volkswagen scandal. The music and speeches that helped raise 40 million kronor in Sweden last night to help refugees. A new article looks to survivors of the Asian tsunami a decade ago for clues on how human beings get better. Producer: Dave Russell.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-08-17 kl. 15.00
item.description: After a fire destroyed part of the old town of Eksjö this weekend, we find out that what makes the town so charming is also what puts it at risk. The Fall political season kicks off with two speeches by party leaders. Then, it may look like an ambulance from the outside, but on the inside it's another story. And finally, according to a new report, there are so many Swedes abroad that if you gathered them all together, they would form the country's second-biggest municipality. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Markus Landén.

item.title: - Radio Sweden
item.description: Hate crimes in Sweden. Details about a wolf hunt that started today to protect farm animals in Dalarna. One woman's story about how a colleague spied on her in a vulnerable situation, and how a new law helped her bring him to justice. The latest theory on why a foetus is sharing the grave of a bishop who died more than 300 years ago. And finally, our summer series looks back at defining moments in Swedish history, with Sweden's strained relationship to Norway during WWII. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou.

item.title: - Radio Sweden
item.description: The serial-rapist Hagmannen has been released from prison today, and emotions in Umeå are running high. The Sweden Democrats recieved 5.2 million crowns from one single donation last year, a donor who can remain anonymous due to a loophole in legislation. We look at the iconic Swedish boxer Ingemar Johansson - and why Swedish television decided not to broadcast one of the biggest sport moments in Swedish history. Pride week continues, and we hear from Americans in Sweden - and how they're marking the occasion in wake of same-sex marriage becoming legal in the US.

item.title: - Radio Sweden
item.description:
Four year anniversary of Anders Behring Breivik's twin terror attacks on Utoya and Oslo, in Sweden's neighboring country of Norway. Find out why so much public money set aside to make summer schools possible is going untouched. Summer series on defining moments in Swedish history continues with a look at the 1912 Olympics. Learn why ice cream makers are having to do without the proverbial cherry on top this summer. And finally, hear what's got Swedes so excited about playing a classic French pasttime, boules. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Frank Radosevich.

item.title: - Radio Sweden
item.description:
Complaints about staffing shortages prompt the health care inspectorate to move in and make an emergency inspection of one Stockholm hospital. Hear the next episode in our summer series on defining moments in Swedish history - today, we talk about a controversial singer of yesteryear, Zarah Leander. A man of means dies leaving behind two vintage roadsters with big question marks as to who will inherit them. And finally, find out why Swedes take so long to bury their loved ones. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Frank Radosevich.

item.title: - Radio Sweden
item.description:
A growing number of suicides on rail tracks. We hear of a new preventative project involving staff on the Stockholm underground. Church weddings are rapidly decreasing..We find out of if it's all down to Swedes' views on religion, And we meet the Swede making life-sized movie props.

Hör om hur alltfler svenska kvinnor som anslutar sig till terrorgruppen IS, och om hur självmord i spårtrafiken kan förebyggas. Bröllop i kyrkor håller på att minska - vi tar reda på om det beror på att religion inte längre är en viktig del i vardagslivet. Dessutom så möter vi mannen som gör filmrekvisita, och vi besöker dansband musikfestivalen.

item.description:
Time is running out for Swedish prosecutors in the Julian Assange case. We speak to the lawyer of one of the alleged victims. Find out why Jet skiers are seen as a growing menace in Sweden and we've a musical flavour to today's programme, including a look back on Sweden's first ever act to top the American billboard charts.

item.title: - Radio Sweden
item.description:
Kommande program

An historic moment as Iran agrees to limit its nuclear activity in return for the lifting of sanctions. History is also made 5 billion kilometres up in outer space as Pluto is brought into view close up for the first time. Our memorable moments in time summer series today looks back on the day when Sweden became the first country in the world to ban the smacking of children.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-07-10 kl. 15.00
item.description: Don't we all want to exterminate those pesky mosquitos? Aerial spray used to kill of larvae before they're born is being questioned by experts. A Swedish aviator is flying cape to cape - reenacting a historic plane ride that took place 86 years ago. LGBTQ-certified asylum-centers? Sweden wants everyone to feel welcomed. And Swedish-Kurdish novelist and Taekwondo champion, Arkan Asaad, talks to Radio Sweden about honour culture, forced marriage, and forgiveness.

item.description: We hear from women who've been exposed to female genital mutilation, and are waiting to undergo surgery to reconstruct their clitorises. More information in English is needed to inform foreign tourists of the potential dangers of hiking through Swedish mountains. We hear from a man who went from London banking to moose farming in Northern Sweden. And today's Defining Moment is when Swedish squatters in the 70's, protesting against the city of stockholm's decision to tear down four houses in the southern part of the city

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-07-08 kl. 15.00
item.description: Neither the police nor fans are pleased with a ten year old law banning violent supporters at football games. Will medical marijuana be legalised in Sweden? We look at one of Sweden's most prominent and notorious spies in modern history, the mysterious Stig Bergling. And we look at Stockholm facades - where several architects are complaining that too few projects see the light of day.

item.description: Having feelings of guilt reportedly go hand in hand with becoming burnt out - especially within elderly care. We speak with Greek Giannis Soleas living in Sweden about the ongoing debt crisis. After pop and assemble-it-yourself furniture, Sweden's next export may be daycare! Have a knack for gardening but live in an apartment? In Sweden you can rent a garden in the middle of the city - if you wait for 25 years!

Our first summer series of the year looks into the mysterious case of the stranded submarine, and we debunk popular myths about vikings.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-07-03 kl. 15.00
item.description: Schools are to be more equal was the main message from the Education Minister Gustav Fridolin in his speech for the Green Party in Almedalen yesterday. We hear from foreign academics struggling to find work in Sweden. This weeks marks the end of the 2013 reopened inquiry into the death of former UN Secretary General, Dag Hammarsköld. From land-fills in Brazil to bringing the EU to court - we hear it all from former Green Party MEP Carl Schlyter.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-07-02 kl. 15.00
item.description: The Green Party dominates in Almedalen today, but there's tension between the party leadership and the grass roots. The government's integration policy has come under fire in a new, critical report presented by the National Audit Office today - but perhaps ice hockey can provide a path to integration? That's what some sports enthusiasts claim. We also bring you a roundup of last night's Almedalen speech - by Sweden Democrat leader Jimmie Åkesson and a report with claims that UberPop drivers are dodging taxes in Sweden. Music: Jag sa till dig by Abidaz. Presenter: Nathalie Rothschild. Producer: Edgar Mannheimer.

And we look at swimming skills - or the lack thereof.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-06-30 kl. 15.00
item.description: Today, we bring you a report from and about the Baltic Sea. We summarise the second out of eight political party leader speeches delivered at Almedalen this week as Social Democrat Prime Minister Stefan Löfven focused on jobs, enterprise, and education. But today in Almedalen, the Christian Democrats are in focus - and party leader Ebba Busch Thor has said that she wants to apply Sweden's road-safety policy, known as Vision Zero, to... abortion.

item.description: No democracy, no guns. Sweden to get tougher rules on arms exports. Bergman-week is underway, but this year the iconic movie-director shares the spotlight with another movie-icon who shares his last name, can you guess who? And we hear from Lisa Sjöblom - who co.-authored an opinion piece about discrimination against Asians in Sweden.

item.description: A new report finds beggars in Sweden suffering threats and acts of violence. And a bankrupt iron ore mine in northern Sweden finds itself in some hot water. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Varma öl och kalla element" by Docenterna.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-06-23 kl. 15.00
item.description: A new video has surfaced showing Swede Johan Gustafsson being held captive in west Africa. The images are the first in months to prove that he may still be alive. And The Sweden Democrats say they have a zero tolerance toward members making racist and anti-immigrant remarks. But we hear about a case that runs counter to that hardline. Foreign tourism is up in Sweden with travelers shelling out hundreds of billions of krona here. We help break down the numbers for you. And a thousand-kilometer long relay race through Europe aims to raise awareness about climate change. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Nothing to worry about" by Peter, Björn and John.

item.description: What are the odds of rain this Midsummer holiday? We ask a betting company. Then, find out the costs of dealing with a perennial problem of summer in Sweden: the nursing shortage. item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-06-11 kl. 15.00
item.description: We'll have the latest on the search in Skaraborg for a teenager who disappeared four days ago. We hear from young Muslims who've started a network to try to stop people from turning to the extremist group IS. Blood donors in Stockholm and other parts of the country can find out exactly when their precious donation has been used to try to save a life. The dark side of the goat cheese industry, thousands of little baby goats are killed here every year to keep things profitable. And we take a peak into one of Sweden's least lagom communities, where one researcher says kids are bred to lead. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Dave Russell.

item.description: Premature babies treated differently depending on the hospital where they're born. Malmö shoot out leads to 27 arrests - "miracle" no one was hurt, say police. News museum (Newseum) in Washington DC honors slain Swedish Radio correspondent, Nils Horner. item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-06-08 kl. 15.00
item.description: Kurds in Sweden are overjoyed with the impressive showing by a pro-Kurdish party in Turkey's national election yesterday. We bring you the reaction from Stockholm. And ten skulls kept in Sweden since the 1880s are being repatriated this week to their home in French Polynesia. Sweden is gearing up for its first match at the women's World Cup in Canada tonight. Stay tuned for our pre-game preview. After six fatal accidents, a railway project in Stockholm is being criticized by former employees for its working conditions. Producer: Dave Russell. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Emmylou" by First Aid Kit.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-06-02 kl. 15.00
item.description: Five thousand days. That's how long Swedish-Eritrean journalist Dawit Isaak has spent imprisoned without trial. We've spoken to his daughter Betlehem. Flocks of tourists heading to the island of Öland will force asylum seekers, who've been living there temporarily, to move on. Nearly half of Sweden's journalists are clumped in one single neighborhood - Södermalm in Stockholm. Is this a problem? And can the Swedish model for biogas be exported to India?

item.title: Radio Sweden Friday
item.description:
Todays program finds out what a Swedish MP with Turkish roots feels about this weeks visit to Stockholm by the Turkish Prime Minister glad for Swedish support for Turkeys entrance into the EU.

And well hear how Swedes eager to reduce down green house gas emissions by cutting down the energy used to heat our houses and apartments. Well also present some of the sounds from the ongoing music festival  Swedish Jazz Celebration   here in the Swedish capital. Closing Music: Peter Asplund, DAYS OF WINE AND ROSES

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-05-20 kl. 15.00
item.description: A new poll finds growing support among Swedes for joining Nato. We hear why. An app that's aimed at checking for diversity in Swedish media has come under fire. We speak to one of its critics. And, Sweden's education system gets a lesson in school leadership from the UK. Finally, we head to Cannes, for another look at the Bergman fever sweeping the festival. Producer: Nathalie Rothchild. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Highwayman" Hoffmaestro and Chraa.

Producer Frank radosevich. Presented by Dave Russell.

item.description: Today, as Sweden celebrates peace day, marking 70 years since the end of World War II, we hear from the great grandson of children's author Astrid Lindgren, whose war diaries have just been published. We also speak to the author of a book about Sweden's foreign policy during the war. And, can and should corporations go green? We're joined in the studio by a Swedish woman who has plenty of ideas about that. Music: Directions by Ane Brun. Presenter: Nathalie Rothschild. Producer: Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-05-05 kl. 15.00
item.description: Hailing a cab in the nation's capital may be really expensive, but you might be surprised to learn that big city taxi drivers have poor working conditions. Several changes are coming to another form of transport, namely Stockholm's bus system. New routes will be added and several existing routes will be ended or changed. Is Gothenburg losing its social and economic identity as a multicultural coastal city with iconic shipyards? And we speak to Swedish Nollywood director Dare Fasasi.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-04-21 kl. 15.00
item.description: After the refugee disasters in the Mediterranean, there is a push to provide more legal routes for migrants who are desperate to get to Europe. Then, how would you feel if the people directing your airplane's landing were nowhere near the runway? We have the story as a small Swedish airport makes aeronautical history. BB And, Swedes think of themselves as environmentally friendly but they might have a weak spot. We'll find out what it is. BB All that and more coming up, but first a roundup of today's top news stories from the Radio Sweden news desk.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-04-09 kl. 15.00
item.description: Sweden is finalising plans to send 35 soldiers to Iraq as part of an international effort to stifle advancements of the Islamic State, and Swedish troops stationed in Mali claim they are not receiving enough food, according to newspaper Dagens Nyheter. Troops speaking to the newspaper say that The United Nations ration of 1800 kilocaleries is too little. Many world-renowned musicians are living in Sweden, but are relatively uknown to the Swedish public. Many of the musicians were forced to flee their countries of origin. I spoke to Iranian singer Safoura Safavi earlier today. And basketball in Sweden is experiencing a rennaissance, comparable to the height of the sport's popularity in the 1980's.

Sony Mobile in Lund has said it will lay off half of its staff. We speak to one the workers wondering about the future. We'll find out who makes Sweden's most perfect cappuccino in a report from the national barista championship And this year's Polar Prize of Music Award: a percussionist and a long standing country music star: Emmylou Harris and Evelyn Glenie. Music: Evelyn Glennie & Barry Wordsworth & National Philharmonic Orchestra Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.description: Saudi Arabia has blocked a speech by Swedish Foreign Minister Margot Wallström, who had received a rare invitation to address the Arab League in Cairo today. We look at the implications of this. A triple murder has shocked the small town of Uddevalla - a major investigation is underway. item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-02-27 kl. 15.00
item.description: About a thousand Muslims gathered around a synagogue in Oslo last week to form a Ring of Peace. Today, something similar is planned in Stockholm. Then, after cases of sexual abuse, student teachers in one city are being banned from changing the diapers of pre-schoolers - some people say that's taking things too far. We'll also hear about new legislation forcing companies to tell you when you're subscription with them is automatically renewed, so you don't get any surprise bills. And Let's Dance? Kris Boswell reports about the comeback of a popular TV show tonight. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli. Producer: Markus Landén.

Presenter: Brett Ascarelli

Producer: Ulla Engberg. Presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

item.description: A clinic in Stockholm provides help for girls who have been subjected to female genital mutilation. Hunters in Värmland and Örebro are out in the forests after a court gave the wolf hunts there a green light. What can you do to stop falling over and breaking a bone on the ice right now? We sent our reporter to find out. And then, one of the most iconic characters in British comedy is to hit the stage for the first time. Blackadder will make his theatre debut here in Stockholm, but why Sweden?

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2015-01-05 kl. 15.00
item.description: - Last year`s big political battleground education: now the government wants to reach a deal with the opposition - but is there enough agreement to build on? Why do you have to wait a year longer for a kidney transplant if you live in Gothenburg, than in Uppsala? We`ll find out why there are really high chances of seeing the northern lights at the moment hat`s in the stars for the country`s postal services - how do you want to have the parcels delivered from your internet shop? And a chance to hear some Swedish celebrities who have agreed to be locked up and filmed 24/7 - spilling the beans about some inner truths. Music: Rikard Wolf "Pojken på månen" Presenter: Ulla Engberg

item.description: Case workers at the Swedish Social Insurance Agency will be trained to spot victims of domestic abuse. Thousands of people just turning 18 would get the right to vote in next year`s snap election - if it takes place. Sweden`s unofficial national anthem could get banned from the airways, depending on the outcome of March`s snap election. And Finnish students want to scrap the compulsory Swedish lessons. Presenter: Ylva Mossing. Producer: George Wood. Music: Öppna Landskap by Ulf Lundell.

item.description: Thousands of people across Sweden couldn`t get online yesterday after a cyberattack struck a telecomm company. Authorities are now taking a closer look at what happened. American whistleblower Edward Snowden sits down for a rare interview with Swedish Television. We`ll tell you what he has to say later. And oh Christmas trees! One group is encouraging people to buy real holiday trees -- and not artificial ones -- to reduce their carbon footprint. Producer: Kris Boswell. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Heartbeats" by The Knife.

item.description: Swedish Prime Minister Stefan Löfven has called a snap election for March. We find out just what can we expect from this rare occurrance. We also talk to a member of the Sweden Democrat party, which brought down the government and ask what her predictions are for the new vote. And: imagine, writing a letter to yourself without being allowed to open it for 20 years. We meet one of the 20,000 Swedes who did just that. Producer: Loukas Christodoulou. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Snälla snälla" by Sarah Riedel and Lonely Dear.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2014-12-01 kl. 15.00
item.description: Whistleblower Edward Snowden is receiving a Right Livelihood Award today via video-link from Russia, and some call for Sweden to give him asylum. One charity organization tries to get people to give during this holiday season without necessarily opening their wallets. With the Stockholm community of Lidingö cancelling its Lucia celebration this year, we look whether the the light of this tradition is starting to dim. And we look at the traditional Yule calendars that the public radio will be airing. Producer / presenter: Brett Ascarelli.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2014-11-21 kl. 15.00
item.description: ---BSK: It wasn`t just the national government that changed hands in September, Stockholm City Council is now run by a red-green-pink coalition. We speak to them. Two Somali-Swedes have been held in custody in the USA for two years facing a terrorism trial, now one of their US lawyers has come to Sweden to try to get some answers. And then at the end of the programme we speak to one of this country`s most well-known photographers.

item.title: SR på engelska - Radio Sweden 2014-11-20 kl. 15.00
item.description: Twenty-five years after its adoption, Sweden says it will introduction the UN convention on the Rights of the Child into law next year. And we sit down with the nation`s first film ambassador who`s job is to put children`s movies in the spotlight. And ask her what type of movies to kids want to see. The Swedish Church is looking into providing housing for refugees here but not everyone is hoping and praying that this comes to pass. And last we meet up with some of the teachers and students who are writing literature in English at Stockholm University. Producer: Brett Ascarelli. Presenter: Frank Radosevich. Song: "Flexibel" by Spinning Jennies.
